statement: The city should fund universal, citywide child care (including extended pre-K/3-K after school hours).
New York should freeze rents for rent-stabilized tenants to immediately reduce housing costs.
Tax increases on the wealthiest New Yorkers and profitable corporations are acceptable to pay for expanded social programs.
The city must build hundreds of thousands of new truly affordable homes over the next decade, using city land and public financing.
Vacant apartments owned by out-of-city owners should be taxed to discourage speculation and help pay for housing programs.
Expedited land-use review and an affordable-housing fast-track are needed to build housing faster (support the 3 ballot amendments).
The mayor must publicly and forcefully oppose federal pressure that threatens city institutions (universities, hospitals, immigrant services).
City hospitals should continue to provide care to undocumented patients even if the federal government threatens to withhold funds.
The mayor should be willing to cooperate with the federal government when it benefits New Yorkers, but be adversarial when federal policy harms the city.
Elected officials who publicly criticize foreign governments (or support protest movements) should not be targeted for deportation by the federal government.
Candidates who identify as socialists or criticize a president should not be considered disqualified from office due to potential federal retaliation.
The city should keep mayoral accountability for education outcomes while sharing more day-to-day decision-making with parents and educators.
Addressing child homelessness, hunger, and family instability is the top priority to improve K-12 learning outcomes.
The city should expand afterschool, weekend, and vocational programs (including more paraprofessionals) to improve learning.
State laws that reduce class size should be enforced; the city should not exempt “popular” schools from class-size rules.
The city should keep and enforce the 15 mph speed limit for e-bikes and penalize delivery apps that enable unsafe riding.
Congestion pricing should be kept (or modified), not abolished, to reduce traffic and fund transit.
Free buses (citywide) are a worthwhile investment if funded to make bus service faster and more reliable.
The city should strictly enforce Local Law 97 and help building owners comply through subsidies and a one-stop procurement for retrofits.
The city may replace some city tasks with AI where it saves money, but must not use AI as an excuse to lay off city workers.
Any large rollout of AI in city jobs must include strong protections and retraining for affected city workers.
The city should dedicate 1% of its budget to parks and green space maintenance.
The city should not expand full-scale commercial casinos in the five boroughs.
Closing Rikers by 2027 should be followed by building smaller, humane borough-based facilities and strong reentry supports.
Hiring several thousand additional police officers is necessary to keep New Yorkers safe.
Quality-of-life enforcement (e.g., prosecuting misdemeanors, addressing street vending, shoplifting) helps prevent violent crime.
The city should create and fund a Department of Community Safety (mental-health outreach + alternative response teams) to handle non-violent, behavioral health calls.
Bail reform should be rolled back to allow stricter pretrial detention for repeat low-level offenders.
The city should place two officers on overnight subway trains to increase rider safety.
The mayor should oppose federal raids and arrest operations carried out in NYC neighborhoods by federal agents without prior city coordination.
The age of adult criminal responsibility should not be raised from 16 years old to 18 years old for most crimes.
The mayor should reduce the number of safe injection sites for drug users in the city.
